Body:
Why is the suffix for [looked] and [hugged] pronounced differently. How can I explain this process via Feature Geometry?

[EDIT] I know the following words respectively sound as follows lʊkt and hʌgd. I also know it has to do with the endings of the words. Words that end in k have a [t] sound with the -ed suffix and the other consonant have the [d] sound. The place of articulation simply allows the words to form like that, however I have to prove that it follows the hierarchiel structure of features and assimilation of the suffix to the final consonant of the stem. Which is where I get stuck, I have not much knowledge about this. Where do I actually start to analyse?
Title: Why the english past tense -ed pronounced differently in some words?
